stem: Dr. {{candidate_name}}, tell me about antiemetic drugs used in anaesthesia.

prompts.text: What are the main classes of antiemetic drugs and give examples?
Explain how ondansetron works and its side effects.
expectedKeyFacts: Blocks receptors in chemoreceptor trigger zone and GI tract
Effective for PONV prevention and treatment
QT prolongation — caution in cardiac patients
More effective when given at end of surgery than at induction

prompts.text: How would you assess a patient's risk of PONV and plan antiemetic prophylaxis?
expectedKeyFacts: Apfel score: female gender, non-smoker, history of PONV/motion sickness, post-op opioids
Each factor = 1 point; 0-1 = low risk, 2 = moderate, 3-4 = high risk
High-risk surgery: laparoscopy, ENT, gynaecological, strabismus surgery
Prophylaxis: multimodal approach if ≥2 risk factors
Combine agents from different classes for additive effect
TIVA with propofol reduces baseline risk
Adequate hydration, minimize opioids, avoid N₂O

prompts.text: A patient develops severe PONV in recovery despite receiving ondansetron intraoperatively. What would you give?
expectedKeyFacts: Prochlorperazine 12.5 mg IM (avoid IV — hypotension risk)
Dexamethasone 4-8 mg IV if not already given
Ensure adequate hydration and minimize opioid dose

prompts.text: Why is dexamethasone commonly used for PONV prophylaxis despite being a steroid?
expectedKeyFacts: Highly effective for PONV prevention (mechanism not fully understood)
Works via anti-inflammatory and central antiemetic effects
Single dose 4-8 mg has minimal side effects
Most effective when given at induction
Concerns: hyperglycaemia (minimal with single dose), delayed wound healing (not clinically significant)
Relative contraindications: active peptic ulcer, poorly controlled diabetes

rescuePrompt: Perhaps you could tell me about the Apfel score — what are the risk factors for PONV?
keyFacts: Apfel score: female, non-smoker, PONV history, opioids
Avoid N₂O, use TIVA, minimize opioids
Combine different classes for additive effect

scoringGuidance.pass: Lists main antiemetic classes with examples, explains ondansetron mechanism and side effects, knows Apfel score and risk stratification, describes multimodal approach, appropriate rescue therapy using different class; stronger candidates discuss optimal timing and dexamethasone rationale
scoringGuidance.borderline: Knows some antiemetics but classification unclear, mentions ondansetron but mechanism vague, aware of PONV risk but Apfel score incomplete, rescue therapy non-systematic
scoringGuidance.fail: Cannot classify antiemetics, does not understand mechanisms, unaware of risk assessment or prophylaxis strategies, inappropriate rescue therapy
